perturbation.original_text: Contractor and Customer agree to terms of payments of current plus thirty (30) days from the date of invoice. Payment shall be affected in US Dollars.
perturbation.changed_text: Contractor and Customer agree to terms of payments of current plus sixty (60) days from the date of invoice. Payment shall be affected in US Dollars.
perturbation.explanation: This change introduces an in-text contradiction. The original contract states payment terms of 'current plus thirty (30) days'. The modification changes it to 'current plus sixty (60) days'. This creates ambiguity and uncertainty regarding the actual payment deadline, as different sections of the contract now provide conflicting information.

perturbation.original_text: In the event that Customer has either cancelled or delayed delivery of a Purchase Order and Customer has not taken delivery of the Products ordered under that Purchase Order within three (3) months from the original delivery date, then; (i) Contractor shall submit a claim for reimbursement for such cancelled or delayed Products within thirty (30) days from the end of such three (3) month period; (ii) Customer shall be liable to pay Contractor 100% of the Contract Price of such cancelled or delayed Products and (iii) Contractor shall hold the cancelled or delayed Products in its inventory and make them available to Customer (upon Customer’s request) for a period of six (6) months from receipt of payment for such Products free of charge. 30 days before the lapse of the 6 month period, the Contractor shall notify the Customer of the upcoming lapse of the term. In the event that Customer, at its sole discretion, decides to repurchase any (or all) of the Products in said Period, and subject to the fulfillment of all Customer’s obligations in this Sections 8.2 (i.e. 100% of the Contract Price has been paid to Contractor), then the price for such repurchase shall be 0% of the Contract Price. Thereafter, the Customer shall pay Contractor all direct costs in connection therewith. Provided Customer hereby authorizes Contractor to transfer such Products to a warehouse operated by Contractor or a third party as instructed by Customer.
perturbation.changed_text: In the event that Customer has either cancelled or delayed delivery of a Purchase Order and Customer has not taken delivery of the Products ordered under that Purchase Order within three (3) months from the original delivery date, then; (i) Contractor shall submit a claim for reimbursement for such cancelled or delayed Products within sixty (60) days from the end of such three (3) month period; (ii) Customer shall be liable to pay Contractor 100% of the Contract Price of such cancelled or delayed Products and (iii) Contractor shall hold the cancelled or delayed Products in its inventory and make them available to Customer (upon Customer’s request) for a period of six (6) months from receipt of payment for such Products free of charge. 30 days before the lapse of the 6 month period, the Contractor shall notify the Customer of the upcoming lapse of the term. In the event that Customer, at its sole discretion, decides to repurchase any (or all) of the Products in said Period, and subject to the fulfillment of all Customer’s obligations in this Sections 8.2 (i.e. 100% of the Contract Price has been paid to Contractor), then the price for such repurchase shall be 0% of the Contract Price. Thereafter, the Customer shall pay Contractor all direct costs in connection therewith. Provided Customer hereby authorizes Contractor to transfer such Products to a warehouse operated by Contractor or a third party as instructed by Customer.
perturbation.explanation: Here, a change from 'thirty (30) days' to 'sixty (60) days' for claim submission introduces a contradiction. This conflicts with other clauses that might reference the original 30-day period, creating ambiguity about the deadline for claim submissions related to canceled or delayed products. This inconsistency affects obligations related to reimbursement claims.

perturbation.original_text: If Contractor holds any FGI based on any forecast for more than three (3) months from the original delivery date specified in the applicable purchase order, Customer shall be required to purchase any and all such goods from Contractor for 100% of Contract Price of such goods and Section 8.3 below shall not apply.
perturbation.changed_text: If Contractor holds any FGI based on any forecast for more than six (6) months from the original delivery date specified in the applicable purchase order, Customer shall be required to purchase any and all such goods from Contractor for 100% of Contract Price of such goods and Section 8.3 below shall not apply.
perturbation.explanation: The term for holding Finished Goods Inventory (FGI) before mandatory purchase by the customer is changed from 'three (3) months' to 'six (6) months'. This contradicts any implicit references to the three-month period in other clauses regarding inventory management or forecasting liabilities, creating confusion and potential dispute over the holding period of FGI.
